StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Field studies of Cryptosporidiosis and Enteropathogens in Bangladesh

Policy.acknowledgement_statement:
Sub-study 1: Acknowledgement statement for phs001476.v1.p1 NIAID/Infection_Malnutrition_Bangladesh/AmebiasisImmunity –
[Funding for the study of Field Studies of Human Immunity to Amebiasis in Bangladesh were provided from the NIH DMID (R01 AI043596-10A1). The datasets used for the analyses described in this manuscript were obtained from dbGaP at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gap/XXXXX through dbGaP study accession numbers xxxxx. Data from the “Field Studies of Human Immunity to Amebiasis in Bangladesh” were provided by William A. Petri, Jr. on behalf of his collaborators at International Center for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Dhaka, Bangladesh and University of Virginia. William A. Petri, Jr. and his collaborators request that publications resulting from these data cite their original publication (Mondal D, Minak J, Alam M, Liu Y, Dai J, Korpe P, Liu L, Haque R, Petri WA Jr. Contribution of enteric infection, altered intestinal barrier function and maternal malnutrition to infant malnutrition in Bangladesh. Clin Infect Dis. 2012 Jan 15;54(2):185-92)].
Sub-study 2: Acknowledgement statement for phs001478.v1.p1 NIAID/Infection_Malnutrition_Bangladesh/Polio_Rotavirus_Vaccines
[Funding for the study of Exploration of the Biologic Basis for Underperformance of Oral Polio and Rotavirus Vaccines in Bangladesh was provided by the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (Grant #: OPP1017093) with additional support from NIH (Grant #: R01 AI043596-17) and the Wellcome Trust (Grant # 098051) for genetic study. The datasets used for the analyses described in this manuscript were obtained from dbGaP at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gap/XXXXX through dbGaP study accession numbers xxxxx. Data from the “Exploration of the Biologic Basis for Underperformance of Oral Polio and Rotavirus Vaccines in Bangladesh” study were provided by William A. Petri, Jr. on behalf of his collaborators at International Center for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Dhaka, Bangladesh, University of Virginia, and University of Vermont College of Medicine.
William A. Petri, Jr. and his collaborators request that publications resulting from these data cite their original publication (Naylor C, Lu M, Haque R, Mondal D, Buonomo E, Nayak U, Mychaleckyj J, Kirkpatrick BD, Colgate ER, Carmolli M, Dickson D, van der Klis F, Weldon W, Oberste MS, PROVIDE study teams, Ma J, Petri WA Jr. Environmental Enteropathy, Oral Vaccine Failure and Growth Faltering in Infants in Bangladesh. EBioMedicine 2015 Sep 25;2(11): 1759–1766)]
Sub-study 3: Acknowledgement statement for phs001665.v1.p1 NIAID/Infection_Malnutrition_Bangladesh/CryptosporidiosisEnteropathogens
[Funding for the study of Field studies of Cryptosporidiosis and Enteropathogens in was provided from NIAID (Grant #: R01 AI043596) and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (Grant #: OPP1017093) with additional support from Wellcome Trust (Grant # 098051) for genetic study.
The datasets used for the analyses described in this manuscript were obtained from dbGaP at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gap/XXXXX through dbGaP study accession numbers xxxxx. Data from the “Field studies of Cryptosporidiosis and Enteropathogens in Bangladesh” studies were provided by William A. Petri, Jr. on behalf of his collaborators at International Center for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Dhaka, Bangladesh, and University of Virginia.
William A. Petri, Jr. and his collaborators request that publications resulting from these data cite their original publication “Steiner KL, Ahmed S, Gilchrist CA, et al. Species of Cryptosporidia Causing Subclinical Infection Associated With Growth Faltering in Rural and Urban Bangladesh: A Birth Cohort Study, Clinical Infectious Diseases, ciy310, https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/ciy310”
Acknowledgement Statement for Sub-Study 4: Bangladesh Environmental Enteric Dysfunction (BEED) Study:
Funding for the study of Field studies of Cryptosporidiosis and Enteropathogens in Bangladesh was provided from NIAID (Grant #: R01 AI043596) and the Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation (Grant #: OPP1017093) with additional support from Wellcome Trust (Grant # 098051) for genetic study.
The datasets used for the analyses described in this manuscript were obtained from dbGaP at http://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/projects/gap/XXXXX through dbGaP study accession numbers xxxxx. Data from the “Field studies of Cryptosporidiosis and Enteropathogens in Bangladesh” studies were provided by William A. Petri, Jr. on behalf of his collaborators at International Center for Diarrhoeal Disease Research, Dhaka, Bangladesh, and University of Virginia.
William A. Petri, Jr. and his collaborators request that publications resulting from these data cite their original publication “Steiner KL, Ahmed S, Gilchrist CA, et al. Species of Cryptosporidia Causing Subclinical Infection Associated With Growth Faltering in Rural and Urban Bangladesh: A Birth Cohort Study, Clinical Infectious Diseases, ciy310, https://doi.org/10.1093/cid/ciy310”

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Controlled-access (GSR are sensitive according to the Institutional Certification)

ConsentGroup.title: Disease-Specific (Tropical Enteropathy, IRB, PUB, NPU, MDS, GSO, RD)
ConsentGroup.name: DS-TENT-IRB-PUB-NPU-MDS-GSO-RD
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction:
Use of the data must be related to Tropical Enteropathy and related disorders. Requestor must provide documentation of local IRB approval. Requestor agrees to make results of studies using the data available to the larger scientific community. Use of the data is limited to not-for-profit organizations. Use of the data includes methods development research (e.g., development of software or algorithms). Use of the data is limited to genetic studies only.
Related disorders may include infectious disease, malnutrition, inflammation, cognitive phenotypes
